string-array.name: product_services
string-array.item: Which products and services are in your existing value proposition?
Which products and services you offer help your customer to get a functional job done?
Which products and services you offer help your customer to get a social job done?
Which products and services you offer help your customer to get a emotional job done?
Which products and services you offer help your customer to satisfy his/her basic needs?
Which products and services help your customer to perform ancillary jobs like a buyer?
Which products and services help your customer to perform ancillary jobs like a co-creator?
Which products and services help your customer to perform ancillary jobs like a transferer?
Which products and services are of type physical or tangible?
Which products and services are of type intangible?
Which products and services are of type digital?
Which products and services are of type financial?
Can you sort all products and services according to their importance for your customer?

string-array.name: gain_creators
string-array.item: Could your products and services create savings that please your customers? In terms of time, money, and effort.
Could your products and services produce outcomes your customers expect or that exceed their expectations? By offering quality levels, more of something, or less of something.
Could your products and services outperform current value propositions and delight your customers? Regarding specific features, performance, or quality.
Could your products and services make your customers\’ work or life easier? Via better usability, accessibility, more services, or lower cost of ownership.
Could your products and services create positive social consequences? By making them look good or producing an increase in power or status.
Could your products and services produce do something specific that customers are looking for? In terms of good design, guarantees, or specific or more features.
Could your products and services fulfill a desire customers dream about? By helping them achieve their aspirations or getting relief from a hardship?
Could your products and services produce positive outcomes matching your customers\’ success and failure criteria? In terms of better performance or lower cost.
Could your products and services help make adoption easier? Through lower cost, fewer investments, lower risk, better quality, improved performance, or better design.

string-array.name: pain_relievers
string-array.item: Could your products and services produce savings? In terms of time, money, or efforts.
Could your products and services make your customers feel better? By killing frustrations, annoyances, and other things that give customers a headache.
Could your products and services fix under-performing solutions? By introducing new features, better performance, or enhanced quality.
Could your products and services put an end to difficulties and challenges your customers encounter? By making things easier or eliminating obstacles.
Could your products and services wipe out negative social consequences your customers encounter or fear? In terms of loss of face or lost power, trust, or status.
Could your products and services eliminate risks your customers fear? In terms of financial, social, technical risks, or things that could potentially go wrong.
Could your products and services help your customers better sleep at night? By addressing significant issues, diminishing concerns, or eliminating worries.
Could your products and services limit or eradicate common mistakes customers make? By helping them use a solution the right way.

Could your products and services eliminate barriers that are keeping your customer from adopting value propositions? Introducing lower or no upfront investment costs, a flatter learning curve, or eliminating other obstacles preventing adoption.

string-array.name: customer_jobs
string-array.item: What is the one thing that your customer couldn\’t live without accomplishing?
What are the stepping stones that could help your customer achieve this key job?
What are the different contexts that your customers might be in?
How do their activities and goals change depending on these different contexts?
What does your customer need to accomplish that involves interaction with others?
What tasks are your customers trying to perform in their work or personal life?
What functional problems are your customers trying to solve?
Are there problems that you think customers have that they may not even be aware of?
What emotional needs are your customers trying to satisfy?
What jobs, if completed, would give the user a sense of self-satisfaction?
How does your customer want to be perceived by others?
What can your customer do to help themselves be perceived this way?
How does your customer want to feel? What does your customer need to do to feel this way?
What supporting jobs surface throughout this life cycle?
How does your customer want to feel? What does your customer need to do to feel this way?
Does the user switch roles throughout this process?

string-array.name: customer_gains
string-array.item: Which savings would make your customers happy?
Which savings in terms of time, money, and effort would they value?
What quality levels do they expect, and what would they wish for more or less of?
How do current value propositions delight your customers?
Which specific features do they enjoy?
What performance and quality do they expect?
What would make your customers\’ jobs or lives easier?
Could there be a flatter learning curve, more services, or lower costs of ownership?
What positive social consequences do your customers desire?
What makes them look good?
What increases their power or their status?
What are customers looking for most?
Are they searching for good design, guarantees, specific or more features?
What do customers dream about?
What do they aspire to achieve, or what would be a big relief to them?
How do your customers measure success and failure?
How do they gauge performance or cost?
What would increase your customers\’ likelihood of adopting a value proposition?
Do they desire lower cost, less investment, lower risk, or better quality?

string-array.name: customer_pains
string-array.item: How do your customers define too costly?
What takes a lot of time, costs too much money, or requires substantial efforts?
What makes your customers feel bad?
What are their frustrations, annoyances, or things that give them a headache?
How are current value propositions under performing for your customers?
Which features are they missing?
Are there performance issues that annoy them or malfunctions they cite?
What are the main difficulties and challenges your customers encounter?
Do they understand how things work, have difficulties getting certain things done, or resist particular jobs for specific reasons?
What negative social consequences do your customers encounter or fear?
Are they afraid of a loss of face, power, trust, or status?
What risks do your customers fear?
Are they afraid of a loss of face, power, trust, or status?
Are they afraid of financial, social, or technical risks, or are they asking themselves what could go wrong?
What\’s keeping your customers awake at night?
What are their big issues, concerns, and worries?
What common mistakes do your customers make?
What are their big issues, concerns, and worries?
Are they using a solution the wrong way?
What barriers are keeping your customers from adopting a value proposition?
Are there upfront investment costs, a steep learning curve, or other obstacles preventing adoption?
